subject: Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... the NUnit ... Sorry if ... with ... still ... If you feel like testing a private method, you should consider refactoring it into a seperate class.  This
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Henry Stapp <hstapp@y...> wrote:
> The 'how to test private methods' question (see below) came up on
the NUnit
> group, and I thought some TDD gurus here might be able to help out.
Sorry if
> this has already been rehashed a hundred times, but I was wrestling
with
> this a lot myself, and despite reading the Wiki threads on this, I
still
> don't have a good 'pattern' to use...
>

If you feel like testing a private method, you should consider
refactoring it into a seperate class. This seems to be a legitimate
code smell. However, that doesn't mean you will always decide to do
so. In those cases, testing them, as private methods, is necessary,
IMHO.

One technique we use, with Java, is to implement our JUnit TestCases
as static inner classes. This gives you the access you require. It
also provides other benefits, especially with TDD. It makes managing
the source a lot easier. You only have to check in/out one file from
SCM. That way you never, ahem, forget the test code. It's always
married to the app code. This helps enforce a mindset that the test
code is just as important as the app code. And it's really
comfortable to bounce up and down the single file in your editor as
you iterate between writing test code and app code. Deployment is
not a problem, since inner classes are compiled into seperate class
files, using the AppClass$TestClass.class naming convention.

Your mileage may vary, but it works pretty well for us. I'd be
interested in others' approaches, as well.

By the way, I'm new here. Nice to meet you all!
